posts.name: Big Bad Breakfast
posts.note: Big Bad Breakfast serves waffles, biscuits, and other hearty daytime eats are served up in a bright, contemporary space. The brainchild of James Beard award-winning chef John Currence, Big Bad Breakfast gives the proper respect to “the most important meal of the day.” Alton Brown recommends the Cathead breakfast, which is a chicken biscuit with crispy fried chicken, cheddar cheese, and sausage gravy. From their website, 'One visit will guarantee you never look at a breakfast plate the same again. Whether it’s the house-cured Tabasco/Brown Sugar Bacon, crispy southern fried chicken, McEwen and Sons grits, or the Anson Mills Steel Cut Oatmeal, you’ll be talking about coming back before you’ve left the table. And don’t forget… we serve lunch too.' NOTE: they have multiple locations.
posts.rcmmnd: Southern Foodways Alliance and Alton Brown

posts.name: Bottega Cafe
posts.note: Bottega Cafe is a relaxed cafe offering fine Italian fare, seasonal specialties, plus wine in a historical setting. Cafe Bottega is Frank and Pardis Stitt’s relaxed spot where you can come for lunch and stay for dinner with a menu celebrating the warm spirit of Italian cuisine while honoring the purest seasonal ingredients of the American South. From their website, ‘Bottega features flavors inspired by the wine bars and trattorias of Italy–from Venice to Palermo. The best aperitifs, wines, beers, cocktails, savory bites, and sublime desserts are offered in a warm and sophisticated atmosphere. Italy inspires the cuisine, carefully crafted by linking ingredients from the American South with artisanal producers from the Italian countryside.’

posts.name: Cafe Dupont
posts.note: Cafe Dupont, around the corner, serves a lovely rabbit gumbo in a white-table-clothed room in a historical building. The chef prepares regional ingredients with a modern Southern spin in a historic, brick-walled bistro. From their website, 'The menu, which changes daily, reflects a fresh perspective on regional ingredients. Classic cooking styles paired with locally grown ingredients create contemporary flavors and signature dishes, such as Fried Oysters & Okra with Cayenne Butter Sauce, Seared Sea Scallops with Goat Cheese Souffle, and Classic Beignets with Home-grown Strawberry Preserves. Café Dupont is a strong supporter of the “slow food” movement, which seeks to encourage the enjoyment of regional produce and traditional foods, which are often grown organically.'

posts.name: El Barrio Restaurante Y Bar
posts.note: El Barrio Restaurante Y Bar is an inventive, sophisticated setting for modern Mexican cuisine and spirits amid bold art and rich woods. Make sure to try their green pozole; it tastes like a Hispanic pho. I read they also make the best salads in town. From their website, 'Multi-regional Mexican-inspired cuisine prepared with seasonally sourced produce, Gulf seafood, and humanely farm-raised meats.'

posts.name: Exotic Wings and Things
posts.note: Exotic Wings and Things is a small place that mostly is carry out for late-night or lunch. Order the lemon-pepper wings, fried okra, and Cajun ranch fries. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Garage Cafe
posts.note: Garage Cafe leads to a wisteria-vined courtyard surrounded by 1930s era parking garages-cum-antique stalls. It is uniquely Birmingham. LIt's a locals' haunt for bustling conversation, beer, and pub grub in a rustic indoor/outdoor setting. It’s also a short stroll down the hill from one of the Southern Foodways Alliance's favorite Birmingham restaurants, Bottega Cafe.

posts.name: Great Wall Chinese Restaurant
posts.note: Great Wall Chinese Restaurant serves Chinese classics, plus Asian fare like hibachi eats and pad Thai, served amid red booths and lanterns. The secret menu at this 30-plus-year old restaurant is the passkey to braised pork belly with smoked mushrooms or the “stir-fried cheese thing” with fermented black beans and chili peppers. From their website, ‘Great Wall Chinese Restaurant is a Chinese cuisine restaurant located in Birmingham, AL. Our menu has a variety of selections for every customer to choose from with reasonable prices. Whether you are looking for the most authentic and tasty Chinese flavored dishes to ignite your tastebuds or something delicate and healthy to satisfy your stomach, China Cafe would always be your wise choice of dining!’

posts.name: Green Acres Cafe
posts.note: Green Acres Cafe serves fried chicken, and fried green tomatoes are served up at this old-school cafe with counter service and founded in 1958 by Charles Gratton. Get a catfish plate, slathered with mustard and battered with cornmeal. Order it with the works, and that gets you slathers of ketchup, mustard and hot sauce on top.

posts.name: Gus's Hot Dogs
posts.note: Gus's Hot Dogs is a tiny joint long known for its eclectic hot dog lineup and special sauce, plus burgers, and breakfast. While the Birmingham hot dog reminds many of people of their past, it is still a vibrant part of the present fabric of the community.

posts.name: Hero Doughnuts
posts.note: Hero Doughnuts is a brick and mortar iteration of a popular pop-up dishing out donuts and burgers until sold out. Owner Wil Drake makes a crazy great apple fritter along with a chicken sandwich that’s as crispy as the fritter. They have fresh, seasonally flavored brioche doughnuts made daily using seasonal and locally sourced ingredients when available — delicious hamburgers on our brioche buns for lunch along with housemade frozen custard.

posts.name: The Lumbar
posts.note: The Lumbar is a new science-themed bar in Pepper Place, situated conveniently near two of our favorite Birmingham restaurants–Chris and Idie Hastings’ Ovenbird with their smoky paella, among other creative and beautifully executed wood-fired menu options; and, Bettola, where we enjoy James Lewis’ Neapolitan-style pizzas, charcuterie, and other seasonal Italian dishes.

posts.name: Mac's One Stop
posts.note: Mac's One Stop has been in the Texaco gas station for nearly 30 years. Heather Ehl runs it with her husband Allen, and it's been a family business since 1986. Heather's father, Mack Cribbs, owned a number of gas station and convenience stores in Birmingham. They had a Shell on 5th before purchasing the current location, which was previously an Exxon and turning it into a convenience store. The lunch menu at Mac's has a selection of burgers, sandwiches, chicken, barbecue, and hot dogs.

posts.name: Mom’s Basement
posts.note: Mom’s Basement has a wide selection of beers, some wine, and a few liquors to enjoy while playing board games or pinball machines. It’s located below the small retail center where Tropicaleo serves fantastic Puerto Rican food.

posts.name: The Nick
posts.note: The Nick delivers all the dive bar essentials: eclectic jukebox, beer-stained pool tables, and decades of smoke-stained live music handbills plastered on every surface. Although restaurants are theoretically walkable from the Nick, arrive and depart via rideshare or taxi. The Nick serves cold beer and rock 'n' roll bring hipsters to this bar and music venue for local and big-name acts.

posts.name: Ollie Irene
posts.note: Ollie Irene is a cozy, vibrant bistro pairing creative seasonal dishes with handcrafted cocktails and beer. Order the catfish with tasso ham, lemon, and a scallion butter sauce with the fries.

posts.name: The Ovenbird
posts.note: OvenBird is Chris and Idie Hastings live fire, casual restaurant. Their menu focuses on the amazing seasonal southern ingredients they know and love in a small plate format that takes inspiration from the live fire traditions of Spain, Portugal, Uruguay, Argentina, and of course the American South. Andrew Zimmern recommends ordering The Boudin Rouge.

posts.name: Post Office Pies
posts.note: Post Office Pies is a stylish outpost for wood-fired pizzas, and local craft beer is located in a historic post office. They started making meatballs which you can get them on pies or as an appetizer. Don't the garlic knots.

posts.name: Shu Shop
posts.note: Shu Shop is a late-night industry place where chefs go for whiskey. People dig the smoked hamachi collar with yuzu salt: Birmingham's home-grown izakaya and ramen shop.

posts.name: The Standard
posts.note: The Standard serves hamburgers, hot dogs, sandwiches, and fries. In the Pizitz Food Hall, Matt Ralph makes an ideal burger. It’s one of those burgers with crispy edges, served on a potato bun. It’s perfect. The hot dogs and fried bologna sandwiches, I'm told are great too.

posts.name: T-Bones Authentic Philly Style Cheesesteaks and Hoagies
posts.note: T-Bones Authentic Philly Style Cheesesteaks and Hoagies sandwiches are served on genuine Amoroso rolls straight from Philly. The thing that makes us unique is that we are a cheesesteak shop first. Anthony “T-Bone” Crawford griddles cheesesteaks and fries Cajun fries.

posts.name: Taco Morro Loco
posts.note: Taco Morro Loco has a taco truck and a brick and mortar. They are cranking out the best of the best in authentic Mexican cuisine. Don’t let the service station exterior scare you away because whether it's tacos, salads, homemade salsa, or nachos piled high, the folks at Taco Morro Loco have got you covered. Make sure to order their chorizo burrito or a carnitas taco with buttermilk tomatillo salsa.

posts.name: Tropicaleo
posts.note: Tropicaleo serves fresh Puerto Rican food in a casual restaurant and bar. Puerto Rican restaurant serves authentic flavors made with local ingredients. The restaurant exudes a Puerto Rico vibe with pastel colors, tropical accents, and laid-back island ambiance. Seating can be found indoors and on the outside terrace. There is also a take-out window for pickup orders.
